page.lettertext:
fol.263r
July
[To]
my L. Trea
s
May it please yo
r
good L. Upon my letters unto yo
u
of
e 15 16 and 19 of this p
nt
I do onely now
attend, what her
Ma
ty
will commaund, for dispatche of
e
companies. It is advertised hether that
e enemy on
e suddaine hath passed
e Rhine, betweene
Berck
&
Wesel
w
th
a 1000 foote and 300 horse. Their purpose is yet
unknowen: but it seemeth by conjecture that they are called
by
Verdugo
to
e castell of
Grolle
, who being there in
son hath a meaning as it is thought, to do somwhat
by surprise in
e quarters of
Zutphen
, w
ch
are very ill
vided
of men & munition, or to seeke to distresse
e camp before
Coeveorden
. The
Councel
at
Swoll
are somwhat
troubled w
th
this occurrence, & have written earnestly unto
mee, that
e Englishe ensignes might be suffred to
repaire to
e campe, or at least to come from
Hattem
,
Hardewick
,
Elbourg
, and those other places remote, where
they lie now in garrison, and be placed at
Disbourghe
for
e assistance of
e towne & of
e contrey joyning to [it]
the self same motion hath bin made by
e
states
that are
heere w
th
urgent speeches of
swasion to draw mee to
allowe theyr coming to
e campe. But both mine
answere unto them & to
e
Councel of state
hath bin to
this effect, that my commission was presise to put
e
companies in a readines w
th
all expedition, & to send them
p
nt
ly from hence when her Hig
nes
should require yt,
This could not be
fourmed nor I excused in
my dealing, if her Ma
ty
having notice of theyr being
in garrison, & wee expecting every howre for theyr
calling from hence, they should be sent abroad againe
to do some service at
e campe. Howbeit for
t
fol.263v
other point of theyr demaund, to have
em placed in
Disbourghe, because I was assured
t
e good estate
of
e contrey was highly tendred by her Ma
ty
, & that to
send
e troupes no further could empeach but very litell
theyr continuance in a redines, I would write about it to
S
r
Francis Vere
(who remaineth at
Utrecht,
& his opinion
therin concurring w
th
mine, wherof I douted not at all,
theyr turne in that respect should be p
nt
ly served. I
knowe not how
e Councel will accept of this answere,
but
e States are not pleased, that theyr power should be
restrained in commanding
e companies. We have
meanes at
is p
nt
that
Count Maurice
, having left
Count
William
at
e siege of Coevoerden, was gone him self w
th
some troupes, & certaine peses of battery before
e sconce of
Detmaersen w
ch
belongeth to
e ennemy in
e southerly
t
of
Twent
. There were not w
th
in above 100 souldiers, w
ch
after
e discharge of 2 or 3 vollies surrendred
e place
upon promise to de
te w
th
theyr weapons, & bagage: but
taking an othe as those of
Steenwick
not to
s
ve
e
King [of]
Spaine
for
e space of six monethes on this side
e Rhine
The forte it is thought doth cost us over deere, hav[ing]
lost before yt by
e shott of a musket
Mons
r
de Fa[uma]
e Governo
r
of
Huesden
& generall of
e artille[ry]
a gentleman of good quallities, of great experience [in the]
warres, & for advise in all attempt
e most su [fficient ] of this contrey.
&c.
